I wouldn't ordinarily advocate for legislation telling the executive branch how to manage a crisis, but I cannot ignore the outcry from my district & state.

We need federal action now, and if the president won't use his authorities, I will do everything I can to push him to act.

Today @RepTimRyan, @RepJohnKatko and I are announcing the Medical Supply Chain Emergency Act, which requires the Admin. to implement the DPA to produce those supplies.

Communities across #MI08 are coming through with donations, but we also need FEMA to rapidly spool up the flow of supplies.

As a member of the House Homeland Security Committee, I am engaging with FEMA on this vital task.

Gov. Whitmer and other governors have asked the federal government to help to mitigate the bidding war between the states.

In my conversations with them, hospitals, health care workers and first responders in my district are increasingly urgent in asking for these supplies.

This is is a good first step. I strongly encourage Rear Adm. Polowczyk to use all the authorities at FEMA’s disposal to accelerate production of tests, masks, gowns, ventilators and other urgently needed items and to distribute them to areas of need.

I’ve seen the President’s tweet about closing the northern border to non-essential traffic.

Understandably, lots of folks in Michigan have unanswered questions about what this means. I hope the administration will issue clearer communication very, very soon.

Regardless of whether or not the President vetoes this legislation, I’m proud that we will have achieved our core aim in introducing the WPR:

We have started a conversation, between both parties & chambers, on Congress’ constitutional role in sending our troops into harm’s way.

This resolution simply re-states what is already required by law: any President must get authorization from Congress before taking us into protracted war.

It states this while making clear that the Admin. always retains the right to act in self defense for ourselves or allies.

Today we took a final vote in the House to pass the bipartisan War Powers Resolution, which passed the Senate on February 13. This is the Senate version of the War Powers Resolution I sponsored, and that passed the House on January 9.

The next stop is the President’s desk.

It’s important for us, as federal leaders, to act decisively to protect public health and to demonstrate our resilience and ability to continue doing the people’s business.

In that spirit, I issued new guidance to my congressional team earlier today, in line with CDC guidance: https://t.co/Spalvyiwdr

I’m a firm believer in smart means to secure our border, but taking another $3.9B on top of the $6.1B that has already been moved out of defense politicizes the Pentagon’s budget in a way that is harmful to the future of our military and to those who live their lives in service.

Whatever one thinks of the wall, Michigan depends on these defense funds that are being diverted, including the $1.5B for the National Guard and Reserves, and the hundreds of millions of dollars for the F-35 fighter program, an aircraft we have a keen interest in bringing to MI.

Earlier today, the House Armed Services Committee got notice that the Administration has decided to again divert funds from the Pentagon’s budget, to continue to build the President’s border wall. https://t.co/I18s24RZvl
It is simply what our Constitution requires, and I'm pleased to see that this legislation has the support of both Democrats and a growing number of Republicans.

Proud to see Senator @timkaine's War Powers Resolution, which includes key provisions of the resolution I introduced in January, pass the Senate today with bipartisan support.

What it means is simple: The President must consult Congress before going to war with Iran.
Michigan State University was founded 165 years ago this week. Happy birthday to @michiganstateu! #GoGreen https://t.co/S41ih7wMWZ
I'm proud to see that Senator @timkaine's resolution, which includes key provisions of my War Powers Resolution, is getting a debate and a vote on the Senate floor this week.

We can't take our eye off the ball when it comes to national security.

It’s important we continue the conversation we started last month around War Powers, and make it clear that any President must get authorization from Congress before taking us into protracted war with Iran.

We need to sound the alarm bells on the cost of insulin. I sat down with Sarah, who will be my guest to the State of the Union on Tuesday, to talk about the 9% of Michiganders who have diabetes, whose insulin costs are through the roof. Here’s what she had to say: https://t.co/M2Fp0ORO8N

2) His comments on ending deportation of Iraqi Christians and minorities, as myself and my colleagues have been pushing for many months. Iraqi minorities are valued members of our communities in Michigan, & deporting them to Iraq puts their lives at risk. https://t.co/n65s2v01uJ

I don’t see eye to eye with the President on everything, but there were two things in his speech tonight, in addition to my support for the new USMCA, that I agreed with:
We owe it to our military –– and to ourselves as a nation –– to provide our troops clarity, and to abide by the Constitution they have sworn their lives to protect.

Bottom line: today's votes contribute to the conversation that started earlier this month around my WPR. 

Together, they reiterate what's in the Constitution: no President can take the U.S. into war without engaging the American public and coming to Congress for authorization.
2) @RepBarbaraLee’s amendment, which would repeal the 2002 AUMF that authorized military force against Saddam Hussein's regime.

1) @RepRoKhanna’s amendment, which says that the President does not currently have the authorization to use protracted force against Iran, and prohibits the use of federal funds for any such military action in or against Iran unless Congress specifically authorizes it.
So what is Congress voting on today? Two pieces of legislation meant to clarify the authority the President does and does not have in using military force:

In fact, Secretary of Defense @EsperDoD publicly affirmed in a House Armed Services Committee hearing on December 11, 2019 that the Administration does not currently have authorization to use force against the state of Iran.

2. The 2002 AUMF authorized President Bush to use military force against the Saddam Hussein regime in Iraq. Given that Saddam fell in 2003, most believe this is an outdated, unnecessary authorization. 

The 2002 AUMF also does not authorize war against the state of Iran.

I am a big believer that the 2001 AUMF should stay on the books until a suitable replacement can be debated and approved.

But the 2001 AUMF does not authorize war against the state of Iran.

1. The 2001 AUMF, which authorized President Bush to use military force against Al Qaeda and its affiliates for their role in the 9/11 attacks.

This 2001 AUMF is very much in use today, as it allows for counter-terrorism operations against Al Qaeda affiliates such as ISIS.
There are currently two Congressional authorizations for the use of military force (AUMF) on the books:

President Trump provided that written notification after killing Qassem Soleimani.

My bipartisan War Powers Resolution simply reiterates the very point of the original WPR:

POTUS must seek Congressional authorization if he intends to use protracted military force against Iran.

In 1973, Congress passed the War Powers Resolution (WPR) with bipartisan support. It says:

POTUS must notify Congress within 48 hrs of initiating the use of military force.

Military force must be terminated within 60 days unless POTUS receives Congressional authorization.

I support this critical right to self defense against imminent threats. And I know from my experience at the Pentagon that there’s simply no way to wait for Congressional approval if an attack on the U.S. or our people is imminent.
The Constitution makes clear that the President always retains the right to self defense against imminent threats, even without coming to Congress for approval in advance.
The President derives authority to use military force from two sources: (1) the Constitution and (2) Congressional authorization.

As an Army wife & stepmom to a daughter & son-in-law in the Army, I feel strongly that issues of war and peace should be publicly debated.

Congress has been derelict in its responsibility for ~20 yrs, under both Dem. & Republican leadership, to seriously address these issues.

Bottom line: these votes help start a necessary conversation on the gravest decisions we in Congress are asked to make -- whether or not to send our troops into war. 

For many of us, this is not a theoretical exercise.

Today, the House will vote on two amendments that address Congress’s role in authorizing the use of military force. 

Given that my War Powers Resolution passed the House on January 9, I thought it important that we put all of these votes into context.
I’m eager to work with Republicans to pass a bipartisan bill that rebuilds our systems to last, and am glad to see @GovWhitmer push for action to get our roads fixed as soon as possible.

No matter if you’re a Democrat, Republican or Independent, the urgent need to fix our roads and infrastructure is something we can all agree on.

This is a bipartisan issue in our communities, and it should be the same way in Congress.
But we’re just getting started. We will continue this fight until every Michigan resident can drink clean water from their tap and swim and fish in clean waters.

PFAS is everywhere in our communities; nearly every living being has detectable levels of PFAS in their blood. 

We must reverse this trend. Clean water must be treated as a right, and we should view the threat to our waters for what it is –– a threat to our homeland security.

In 2014, the U.S. and Iraq quickly negotiated the terms of U.S. force presence through an Exchange of Letters, which remains the only agreement on the books that authorizes U.S. military personnel in Iraq. I represented the Pentagon in those negotiations.
